patterns: I've been having trouble with my thoughts and feeling like people are watching me. It's been affecting my daily life.
responses: It sounds like you may have schizophrenia. We can prescribe medications such as Risperidone, Benztropine, Olanzapine (Zyprexa), Haloperidol, Quetiapine (Seroquel), Divalproex Sodium (Depakote), Aripiprazole (Abilify), Ziprasidone (Geodon), Clozapine, Fluphenazine (Prolixin), Lithium (Li), or Perphenazine to help alleviate your symptoms. We'll work together to determine which medication will be best for you.

patterns: Hi doctor, I think I might have a knee injury. I was playing basketball and I landed awkwardly on my knee. Now it's really swollen and painful.
responses: Based on your symptoms, it sounds like you might have a tear in your knee ligament or meniscus. We will need to perform a procedure to fix it. You'll be given anesthesia, such as Propofol, Bupivacaine or Sevoflurane, to keep you asleep and pain-free during the procedure. We might also administer Cortisone and Sodium Hyaluronate to reduce inflammation and help with the healing process. Additionally, Nitrous Oxide, Thiopental (Pentothal), and Rocuronium may be used to make sure you are completely relaxed and muscularly paralyzed during the procedure. Afterward, we may prescribe Clidinium (Librax) and Penbutolol (Levatol) to help with any post-operative pain or discomfort.

patterns: Doctor, I have recently been diagnosed with Endocarditis. What medications do I need to take?
responses: You will need to take Warfarin, Digoxin, Rosuvastatin (Crestor), Ramipril, Alfuzosin (Uroxatral), Darbepoetin Alfa (Aranesp), Bumetanide, Loperamide (Imodium), and Rabeprazole (Aciphex) to treat your Endocarditis.

patterns: Hello doctor, I've been feeling very sick lately. I have a high fever, chills, and my body aches all over. My blood pressure is also very low and I feel extremely weak.
responses: Based on your symptoms, it sounds like you may be experiencing sepsis. This is a serious condition that requires immediate medical attention. I will be prescribing you a combination of medications to treat this condition. You will need Ceftriaxone, Vancomycin, Levofloxacin (Levaquin), Zosyn, Dopamine, Gentamicin Ophthalmic, Cefepime, Ampicillin, Norepinephrine, Cefotaxime, Sodium Polystyrene Sulfonate (Kayexalate), and Meropenem.

patterns: Doctor, I think I have a heat stroke.
responses: You need to take air immediately to cool down your body. Later, you will need to take Alprazolam (Xanax), Indapamide, Varenicline (Chantix), Olmesartan (Benicar), Pravastatin, Zolpidem (Ambien), Warfarin, Cyclobenzaprine, Amlodipine, and Mecamylamine to prevent further complications.

patterns: Hi doctor, I have recently been diagnosed with Cholecystitis, can you prescribe me some medications for it?
responses: Yes, sure. For Cholecystitis, you need to take a combination of medications including Meperidine (Demerol), Zosyn, Propofol, Rocuronium, Cefoxitin, Sevoflurane, Glycopyrrolate, Cefotetan, Neostigmine, and Butorphanol (Stadol).

patterns: Doctor, I had a cardiac arrest last night, and I am feeling very weak, what medications do I need to take?
responses: Based on your condition, you need to take Epinephrine, Atropine (Uaa), Sodium Bicarbonate, Amiodarone, Dopamine, Diltiazem, Norepinephrine, Potassium Bicarbonate, Naloxone (Suboxone), Propofol, Vecuronium, and Magnesium Sulfate.

patterns: Doctor, I have been diagnosed with cardiomyopathy. What medications do I need to take?
responses: You need to take Carvedilol, Furosemide, Lisinopril, Warfarin, Spironolactone, Digoxin, Amiodarone, Enalapril, Rosuvastatin (Crestor), Ramipril, Losartan, and Isosorbide.

patterns: Hi doctor, I think I have a social phobia. I feel extremely anxious and uncomfortable in social situations and it's affecting my daily life.
responses: The medications which can be prescribed for social phobia include clonazepam, sertraline, alprazolam, bupropion, quetiapine, citalopram, paroxetine, fluoxetine, duloxetine, lamotrigine, venlafaxine, and aripiprazole. We'll start with clonazepam and see how your body reacts to it.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing severe headaches and a high fever. I also feel really nauseous and dizzy. What could be wrong with me?
responses: Based on your symptoms, it's possible that you have meningitis. To treat this infection, you will need to take a combination of medications, including ceftriaxone, vancomycin, ampicillin, prochlorperazine (Compro), midazolam (Versed), cefotaxime, acyclovir, phenobarbital, gentamicin ophthalmic, cefuroxime, micafungin, and amphotericin B.

patterns: Doctor, I have been recently diagnosed with spherocytosis. What medications do I need to take?
responses: You don't need to worry, we have a combination of medications for your treatment. You'll need to take Methylphenidate, Mecamylamine, and Magnesium Lactate.

patterns: Doctor, I've been feeling really off lately and I think it might have something to do with a hormone disorder.
responses: Okay, based on your symptoms and diagnosis, I am going to prescribe you with Leuprolide, Phentermine, Estradiol, Progesterone, Testosterone, Mitotane, Histrelin, Fludrocortisone, Chlorhexidine Topical, Phendimetrazine, Gemcitabine, and Minocycline.

patterns: Hi Doctor, I have been experiencing severe numbness and tingling in my fingers and toes which turn white and blue when I get cold or stressed. I think I may have Raynaud disease. What medications should I take?
responses: Based on your symptoms and diagnosis of Raynaud disease, I recommend you take Nifedipine, Mycophenolate Mofetil (Cellcept), or Hydroxychloroquine (Plaquenil) to manage the symptoms.

patterns: I have been having joint pain and swelling after a recent bowel infection. My doctor said it could be reactive arthritis. What medications do I need to take?
responses: For reactive arthritis, the required medications are Methotrexate, Sulfasalazine, Dexamethasone Topical Product, Folic Acid, and Methylprednisolone (Medrol). However, Air, Mecamylamine, Troleandomycin, Indium Oxyquinoline In-111 (Indium In-111 Oxyquinoline), and Pipecuronium (Arduan) are not used for this condition.

patterns: Doctor, I think I have scabies, I have been experiencing intense itching and some red bumps on my skin.
responses: The required medication for scabies is permethrin topical.

patterns: Doctor, I think I might have an ear wax impaction. My ears feel clogged and I'm having trouble hearing.
responses: Yes, it sounds like you may have ear wax buildup. I recommend using Carbamide Peroxide Otic or Triethanolamine Polypeptide Oleate Otic drops to help soften and remove the wax. If those don't work, we can try Hydrogen Peroxide Topical or Carbamide Peroxide Topical drops. In rare cases with severe impactions, I may need to use Fluocinolone Otic to reduce inflammation or Mineral Oil for a stye. If you're experiencing any itching or sneezing, it may be from allergies, and in that case, I recommend Olopatadine Nasal. But, if you're experiencing anxiety, I can prescribe Chlorpromazine (Thorazine) to help manage any symptoms.

patterns: Doctor, I have been having high blood pressure during my pregnancy. What do you think is the required medication for me?
responses: The required medications for hypertension of pregnancy are Atenolol, Labetalol, Nifedipine, Methyldopa, Hydralazine, Terbutaline, Thioridazine, and sometimes even Rubella Virus Vaccine. Other than that, you might also be given Ferrous Sulfate, Propylthiouracil, Oxytocin, and even Lactic Acid Topical for certain symptoms.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing severe pain and numbness in my leg, and I was diagnosed with Peripheral arterial embolism. What medications do I need to take?
responses: You will need to take Warfarin, Heparin, Enoxaparin (Lovenox) to prevent clots, and Isosorbide Dinitrate to improve blood flow. These medications will help manage your symptoms and reduce the risk of complications.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing redness, pimples, and visible blood vessels on my face. The redness gets worse when I expose my skin to sunlight or when I drink alcohol.
responses: You might be suffering from Rosacea. I would recommend some medications such as Metronidazole Topical Product, Doxycycline, Azelaic Acid Topical or Minocycline. These medications can help to reduce the inflammation and redness on your face. You should also avoid triggers like spicy foods or harsh weather.

patterns: Hello doctor, I think I might have fractured my skull. I'm experiencing a severe headache and dizziness. What medication do I need?
responses: Based on your symptoms and diagnosis, you'll need a few medications. You should get a Tetanus Toxoid Vaccine (Adacel) to prevent tetanus infection. To prevent infection, you need Cefazolin. Besides, you'll need Diphtheria Toxoid Vaccine (Prohibit).To manage your symptoms and pain, I recommend Mannitol and Dapsone. For the dizziness, you'll need Dopamine. For seizures, you should take Fosphenytoin. And for pain management, you'll need Lidocaine-Prilocaine Topical.

patterns: Hi doctor, I have been experiencing eye pain, redness, and light sensitivity. I went to an eye specialist and was diagnosed with uveitis. What medications do I need to take?
responses: Your uveitis will require various medications. The required medications for your treatment include Cyclopentolate Ophthalmic, Prednisone, Triamcinolone Ophthalmic, Suprofen Ophthalmic, Loteprednol Ophthalmic, Brimonidine-Timolol Ophthalmic, Brinzolamide Ophthalmic, Nepafenac Ophthalmic, Infliximab (Remicade), Proparacaine Ophthalmic, Atropine (UAA), and Prednisolone Ophthalmic.

patterns: Hi doctor, I recently got into an accident and I think I have a fracture of the facial bones. What medication do I need to take?
responses: Based on your condition, you will require several medications. You need to take Tetanus Toxoid Vaccine (Adacel) to prevent tetanus infection. Oxymetazoline Nasal will help relieve nasal congestion. Cefazolin will help prevent infections. Desflurane is an anesthetic gas that will be given during the surgery for pain control. Cyclopentolate Ophthalmic will help dilate your pupils. Sterile Water will be used for irrigation. Bacitracin Topical and Hexachlorophene Topical will aid in wound healing, and Cocaine Topical will be used for numbing. Finally, Scopolamine will help prevent nausea and vomiting due to anesthesia.

patterns: Doctor, I've been experiencing cough, difficulty breathing and chest pain for the past few days. I'm worried it may be tracheitis.
responses: Based on your symptoms, it is possible that you have tracheitis. You will need to be prescribed medication to treat your condition. You will need to take Guaifenesin (Mucinex), Clarithromycin, Prednisolone, Levalbuterol (Xopenex), Benzonatate, Budesonide, Moxifloxacin (Avelox), Levodopa, and Ceftazidime.

patterns: Hi Doctor, I have been experiencing a lot of pain in my jaw and I can barely eat or speak. I think I have a jaw disorder.
responses: Based on your symptoms, I recommend a combination of medications. You will need to take penicillin and Clindamycin to get the infection under control. You will also need to use Chlorhexidine Topical and Benzoin Topical to help reduce inflammation and pain.Additionally, you may need Tetanus Immune Globulin, Human if you have not had a tetanus shot within the last 10 years. Methenamine, Aztreonam, and Voriconazole may also be prescribed depending on the severity of your condition. In extreme cases, you may be given Desflurane as a general anesthetic for surgical intervention.Please follow the recommended guidelines and dosages as prescribed to minimize complications and complications that may arise from the condition.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing pain around my rectum and discharge. I think it might be a perirectal infection.
responses: Yes, it does appear to be a perirectal infection. I will prescribe you Clindamycin, Zosyn, Magnesium Sulfate, Nitrofurazone Topical, Diflorasone Topical, Insulin, Glulisine, Human (Apidra), Pramoxine Topical, Halobetasol Topical, Paricalcitol (Zemplar), Ferrous Sulfate, and a Diphtheria Toxoid Vaccine (Prohibit) to treat the infection.

patterns: Doctor, I've been diagnosed with a breast cyst. What medications do I need to take?
responses: You will need to take Triamterene, Telmisartan (Micardis), Imipramine, Norethindrone (Loestrin Fe), and Primidone to treat your breast cyst. Please follow the medication instructions carefully and come back for a follow-up appointment in two weeks.

patterns: Hi doctor, I have been experiencing severe anxiety, nightmares, and flashbacks after a traumatic event. I'm having trouble sleeping and it's affecting my daily life.
responses: I believe you are suffering from Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). I recommend medications such as Clonazepam, Quetiapine (Seroquel), Trazodone, Bupropion (Wellbutrin), Fluoxetine (Prozac), Risperidone, Lamotrigine (Lamictal), Aripiprazole (Abilify), Mirtazapine, Lithium (Li), Olanzapine (Zyprexa), and Eszopiclone (Lunesta) to alleviate your symptoms.

patterns: Doctor, I have been diagnosed with kidney cancer. What medication do you recommend for my treatment?
responses: You will require a combination of medications for your treatment. Sunitinib (Sutent), Temsirolimus, Vincristine, Zoledronic Acid (Reclast), Everolimus (Afinitor), Filgrastim (Neupogen), Doxorubicin, Travoprost (Travatan), Dactinomycin, Sorafenib, Ioversol, and Midodrine are some of the medications that we will use depending on your condition and response to treatment.

patterns: Hi doctor, I've been experiencing some redness, swelling, and itchiness in my eyelids. My eyes also feel dry and gritty. I think I might have blepharitis.
responses: Yes, it sounds like you have blepharitis. The medications you need to take are azithromycin ophthalmic, erythromycin ophthalmic, and ocular lubricant.

patterns: Hi doctor, I've been struggling with Celiac disease for quite some time now. What medications would you recommend for me?
responses: I suggest you take a combination of Estradiol, Ketotifen Ophthalmic, and Aloe Vera Topical to alleviate your symptoms. It's important to adhere to a strict gluten-free diet as well.

patterns: I have a burning sensation when I pee and I heard it could be cystitis, what medication should I take?
responses: You should take Ciprofloxacin, Phenazopyridine (Azo), Bactrim, Nitrofurantoin, Pentosan Polysulphate Sodium (Elmiron), Trimethoprim, Solifenacin (Vesicare), Darifenacin (Enablex), Dimethyl Sulfoxide Topical, Dexlansoprazole (Dexilant), Silver Protein Mild Topical or Flavoxate (Urispas) depending on the severity of your symptoms and other factors. I'd like to examine you before prescribing a specific medication.

patterns: Hi doctor, I have been recently diagnosed with sickle cell anemia. Can you please suggest me the required medications?
responses: Yes, for sickle cell anemia, you will need to take several medications including Folic Acid, Hydroxyurea, Penicillin, Deferasirox (Exjade), Deferoxamine, Nelfinavir (Viracept), Pirbuterol (Maxair), Benzylpenicilloyl Polylysine (Pre-Pen), Zidovudine, Lamivudine, Factor VIII, and Mesna.

patterns: Doctor, I have a subconjunctival hemorrhage in my eye.
responses: You will require Tetracaine (One Touch), Fluorescein Ophthalmic, and Prednisolone Ophthalmic eye drops.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing pain and discomfort in my anal area. I suspect I may be suffering from hemorrhoids.
responses: I see. Given your symptoms, I would recommend a few medications to help with the hemorrhoids. You will need to take Midazolam (Versed), Docusate (Colace), Hydrocortisone Topical, Fentanyl, Meperidine (Demerol), Psyllium, Hydrocortisone-Pramoxine Topical, Hydrocortisone, Pramoxine Topical, Methylcellulose (Citrucel), Calcium Polycarbophil (Fibercon), and Dibucaine Topical.

patterns: Doctor, I have a skin condition where my skin is red, itchy, and swollen after coming in contact with certain substances. What medication do I need?
responses: Based on your symptoms, I recommend using Hydrocortisone Topical, Triamcinolone, or Desonide Topical to reduce the inflammation and itching. You may also benefit from taking an oral antihistamine like Hydroxyzine to ease the itching. If the affected area is particularly severe, you may need a stronger medication like Clobetasol Topical, Fluocinonide Topical, Betamethasone Topical Product, Pimecrolimus Topical, Betamethasone-Clotrimazole Topical, or Desoximetasone Topical. Additionally, applying Petrolatum Topical may help protect and soothe the affected skin.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing fatigue and shortness of breath lately. My heart rate seems to be slower than usual.
responses: It sounds like you may be experiencing sinus bradycardia. I am going to prescribe you a medication called Nebivolol (Bystolic) to help regulate your heart rate.

patterns: Doctor, I was diagnosed with high blood pressure a few days ago. What medications do I need to take to control it?
responses: You will need to take four medications to control your high blood pressure - Hydrochlorothiazide, Amlodipine, Olmesartan (Benicar), and Benazepril. These medications work together to lower your blood pressure and manage any symptoms you may have.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing abdominal pain, fever and unusual discharge. Upon visiting the hospital, I was diagnosed with pelvic inflammatory disease. What medications do I need?
responses: In order to treat your pelvic inflammatory disease, you will need to take a combination of antibiotics such as doxycycline, ceftriaxone, metronidazole, cefoxitin and gentamicin. Additionally, you may also require Iohexol (Omnipaque), Diatrizoate or Ampicillin depending on the severity of the infection. For topical relief, you can use Metronidazole or Miconazole Topical Product. If needed, we may also prescribe neostigmine or cefixime (Suprax) to help alleviate any related symptoms.

patterns: Hello doctor, I have been recently diagnosed with liver disease. Can you please tell me what medications I need to take?
responses: Yes, for your liver disease, you will need to take spironolactone, lactulose, Ursodiol (Urso), Nadolol, Tacrolimus (Prograf), Ritonavir (Norvir), Lamivudine, Atazanavir (Reyataz), Kaletra, Stavudine (Zerit), Pancreatin, and Zidovudine.

patterns: Hi doctor, I have been experiencing chronic constipation for quite some time now. What medications can I take?
responses: Based on your condition, you can take Polyethylene Glycol 3350 (Miralax), Docusate (Colace), Magnesium Citrate, Bisacodyl (The Magic Bullet), Lactulose, Glycerin (Fleet), Psyllium, Sennosides, Usp (Perdiem), Mineral Oil (Stye), Guar Gum, or Benzylpenicilloyl Polylysine (Pre-Pen).

patterns: Doctor, I've been diagnosed with thyroid cancer, what medications will I be taking?
responses: You will be taking a combination of medications to treat your thyroid cancer. These include Thyroxine (Synthroid), Triiodothyronine (Cytomel), Risedronate (Actonel), Thyroid (Usp) (Armour Thyroid), Paricalcitol (Zemplar), Doxorubicin, Carboplatin, Miglitol (Glyset), Thyrotropin Alfa (Usp) (Thyrogen), and Eflornithine Topical. These medications will help to slow the growth of cancer cells and prevent the spread of the disease.

patterns: Hi Doctor, I think I have the flu. I have a fever, cough, and sore throat. What do I need to take?
responses: Based on your symptoms, it sounds like you have the flu. The medications you need to take are Oseltamivir, Zanamivir, or Amantadine. I would also recommend taking Robitussin Ac or Dm to help with the cough and sore throat.

patterns: Doctor, I have been diagnosed with Friedrich ataxia, what medication should I take?
responses: You will need to take Fluticasone Nasal Product, Albuterol, Oxcarbazepine (Trileptal), Sildenafil (Viagra), Polyethylene Glycol 3350 (Miralax), Digoxin, Omeprazole, Air, Mecamylamine, Troleandomycin, and Indium Oxyquinoline In-111 (Indium In-111 Oxyquinoline) to manage your Friedrich ataxia.

patterns: Hello, doctor. I have been recently diagnosed with a skin polyp. What do you suggest for medications?
responses: For a skin polyp, the required medications may include Tretinoin Topical, Benzoyl Peroxide Topical, Ciclopirox Topical, Salicylic Acid Topical, Aluminum Chloride Hexahydrate Topical, Hydroquinone Topical, Adapalene Topical, Benzoyl Peroxide-Clindamycin Topical, Desoximetasone Topical, Imiquimod Topical or Azelaic Acid Topical depending on the severity of the polyp. We can discuss further and decide on the best treatment option for you.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing severe pain and numbness in my shoulder and arm. I also have trouble moving my arm properly.
responses: Based on your symptoms, it seems like you may have brachial neuritis. To treat your condition, I am going to prescribe you a combination of Carisoprodol (Soma), Metaxalone (Skelaxin), Piroxicam, Flurazepam, Oxymorphone (Opana), Pentosan Polysulphate Sodium (Elmiron), Quinine and Bilberry Extract. These medications will help to relieve your pain, reduce inflammation, and improve your mobility. Please take them as instructed and come back to me for a follow-up appointment.

patterns: Doctor, I have been diagnosed with cervical cancer, what medications am I supposed to take?
responses: You need to take a combination of medications for your cervical cancer. You'll be given Potassium Chloride, Ortho Cyclen, Cisplatin, Acetic Acid Topical, Paclitaxel (Taxol), Midrin, Norethindrone (Loestrin Fe), and Pegfilgrastim (Neulasta) to manage and treat your condition.

patterns: Hi doctor, I was recently diagnosed with Adrenal Adenoma. Can you tell me what medications I need to take?
responses: Yes, for Adrenal Adenoma, you will need to take Phenoxybenzamine, Rabeprazole (Aciphex), Polyethylene Glycol 3350 (Miralax), Ferrous Sulfate, Peginterferon Alfa-2B (Sylatron), Ribavirin, Calcium-Vitamin D, Tacrolimus (Prograf), Bisacodyl (The Magic Bullet) and Fosinopril.

patterns: Doctor, I have been having trouble swallowing and feel a burning sensation in my chest, I think I might have esophagitis. What do you recommend for treatment?
responses: I recommend taking a course of medication such as Omeprazole, Pantoprazole, Lansoprazole (Prevacid), or Rabeprazole (Aciphex) to reduce stomach acid and heal the esophagus. Additionally, you may benefit from taking Sucralfate (Carafate) to coat and protect the esophagus, Simethicone (Degas) to reduce gas, and Benzocaine Topical for local pain relief. If needed, we can also administer Midazolam (Versed) for sedation during any procedures, or Propofol for deeper sedation.

patterns: Doctor, I think I have contracted Gas gangrene.
responses: I am sorry to hear that. You need to take a combination of medications for this condition. I am prescribing you Meropenem, Air, Mecamylamine, Troleandomycin, Indium Oxyquinoline In-111 (Indium In-111 Oxyquinoline), Pipecuronium (Arduan), Grepafloxacin (Raxar), Rabbit Anti-Human T-Lymphocyte Globulin (Thymoglobulin), Iopanoic Acid, Conjugated Estrogens Topical, and Malathion Topical.

patterns: Doctor, I have been feeling some discomfort and itching down there. I think I might have a yeast infection. What medication should I take?
responses: I recommend taking Fluconazole (Diflucan) to treat the yeast infection. Additionally, you can use Nystatin Topical Product, Clotrimazole Topical, Miconazole Topical Product, Terconazole Topical, Betamethasone-Clotrimazole Topical, Butoconazole Topical, or Zinc Oxide Topical to relieve the symptoms. If you are also experiencing pain during intercourse, then you can take Pentosan Polysulphate Sodium (Elmiron). Lastly, I recommend taking a hormonal birth control pill such as Ortho Cyclen or Portia to prevent future yeast infections.

patterns: Doctor, I have been diagnosed with Spina bifida. What medication do I need to take?
responses: You will need to take a combination of medications for your condition. These medications include Oxybutynin, Polyethylene Glycol 3350 (Miralax), Budesonide, Sennosides Usp (Perdiem), Guar Gum, Oxcarbazepine (Trileptal), Tobramycin (Tobi), Epoetin Alfa (Procrit), Cromolyn (Viz-On), Somatropin, Cellulose, and Calcium Acetate.

patterns: Doctor, I think I may have poisoned myself with my medication. What should I do?
responses: You need to take a few medications right away to counteract the poisoning. You need to take charcoal, naloxone (Suboxone), acetylcysteine, sodium bicarbonate, thiamine, flumazenil, magnesium sulfate, and ritonavir (Norvir).

patterns: Doctor, I have been drinking heavily for the past few years and I am now experiencing symptoms such as jaundice, fatigue, and abdominal pain. I am worried that I might have alcoholic liver disease.
responses: Yes, it does sound like you may have alcoholic liver disease. We will need to start you on a combination of medications to help manage your condition. You will need to take Furosemide and Spironolactone to reduce fluid buildup in your body. You will also need to take Lactulose to reduce the amount of ammonia in your body. Additionally, you will need to take Folic Acid, Pantoprazole, and Thiamine to help support liver function. We will also prescribe Propranolol and Nadolol to reduce the risk of bleeding from varices. Finally, you will need Octreotide, Midodrine, and Zinc Sulfate to manage other symptoms you may experience.

patterns: Hi doctor, I have been experiencing really high blood pressure and severe headaches. I'm scared that it might be malignant hypertension. What medication should I take?
responses: Based on your symptoms, I think it's highly likely that you have malignant hypertension. I recommend that you take a combination of Labetalol, Nitroglycerin, Clonidine, Hydralazine, Nicardipine, Nitroprusside, and Mexiletine.

patterns: Doctor, I think I might have diverticulitis. I have been experiencing abdominal pain, constipation, and feverishness.
responses: Based on your symptoms, it is likely that you have diverticulitis. I am going to prescribe you a combination of antibiotics such as Metronidazole, Ciprofloxacin or Levofloxacin (Levaquin) to fight the infection. If needed, you may also require a stronger antibiotic like Zosyn. Additionally, I suggest taking Psyllium to improve bowel movements and appetite. Please avoid using any contrast agents like Diatrizoate, Iohexol (Omnipaque), Barium Sulfate, or Iopamidol (Isovue) that could worsen your symptoms. If you have any eye infection, we can treat it with Besifloxacin Ophthalmic.

patterns: Doctor, I was recently diagnosed with Moyamoya disease. Could you please tell me what medications I will need to take?
responses: You will need to take a combination of medications to manage your Moyamoya disease. These include aspirin, carbamazepine, risperidone, folic acid, scopolamine, hydroxyurea, glycopyrrolate, zonisamide, chlorhexidine topical, metaxalone (Skelaxin), and labetalol.

patterns: Hi doctor, I think I have heat exhaustion. I feel tired, weak and dizzy, and my skin is clammy.
responses: I'm sorry to hear that. Heat exhaustion is a serious condition caused by dehydration and a lack of electrolytes in your body. I'm prescribing you Potassium Bicarbonate to replenish your electrolytes and restore your body's balance.Patient: Is that all I need to take?

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing some symptoms of psychotic disorder like delusions, hallucinations and disorganized thoughts. What medications do I require for this disease?
responses: For treating psychotic disorder, the medications that are required include Risperidone, Quetiapine (Seroquel), Aripiprazole (Abilify), Olanzapine (Zyprexa), Haloperidol, Divalproex Sodium (Depakote), Methylphenidate, Benztropine, Ziprasidone (Geodon), Oxcarbazepine (Trileptal), Lithium (Li), and Atomoxetine (Strattera).

patterns: Doctor, I think I have frostbite on my toes, can you please prescribe me some medication for it?
responses: Sure, for frostbite, I am prescribing you 'Silver Sulfadiazine Topical'.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing a decrease in the size and firmness of my penis during erections. I am really worried about it.
responses: Based on your symptoms, I believe you are suffering from Atrophy of the corpus cavernosum. In order to treat this condition, I recommend that you take Sildenafil (Viagra) and/or Testosterone. These medications will help to improve blood flow to the penis and increase the size and firmness of erections.

patterns: Hi doctor, I am addicted to smoking and I need help.
responses: I can prescribe you Varenicline (Chantix) to help you quit smoking.

patterns: Hi doctor, I think I sprained my ankle while playing basketball yesterday. It's swollen and hurts a lot.
responses: I'm sorry to hear that. I recommend taking some pain relievers, such as Ketoprofen, to reduce the inflammation. Additionally, I can prescribe you some muscle relaxants, like Cyclobenzaprine, Methocarbamol, Metaxalone (Skelaxin), or Orphenadrine (Flexon) to help with the pain and muscle spasms.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing tremors in my hands and my head shakes involuntarily. What could be the cause of this?
responses: You are most likely experiencing essential tremors. But don't worry, there are various medications that can help with your symptoms. I would advise that you take Primidone, Propranolol, Gabapentin, Topiramate (Topamax), Trihexyphenidyl (Artane), Amantadine, Torsemide, or Pramipexole (Mirapex) depending on what works best for you.

patterns: Hi Doctor, I have an open wound in my ear. What medication do I need?
responses: Based on your condition, the required medications for you are Cephalexin, Bacitracin (Septa), Tetanus Toxoid Vaccine (Adacel), Cefazolin, Povidone Iodine Topical (Betadine), Ofloxacin, Neomycin (Septa), Ketamine, Demeclocycline, Lidocaine Topical Product, and Emollients, Topical.

patterns: Hi doctor, I think I have a foreign body in my nose. It's been bothering me for a few days now and I can't seem to get it out.
responses: Alright, I recommend taking Phenylephrine (Duramax) or Oxymetazoline Nasal. This will help open up your nasal passages and possibly dislodge the foreign body. If that doesn't work, we may need to use Ketamine to sedate you and remove the object safely.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing very painful and unusual menstrual cramps every month. I don't know what to do, it's really affecting my daily routine.
responses: I understand, it sounds like you have idiopathic painful menstruation. To help alleviate your symptoms, I would recommend taking a combination of medications such as Ortho Cyclen, Medroxyprogesterone, Mefenamic Acid, Portia, Modicon, Leuprolide (Lupron), Rofecoxib (Vioxx), and Valdecoxib (Bextra). These medications will help regulate your menstrual cycles and ease the pain you are experiencing.

patterns: Hello doctor, I have Down syndrome and I'm wondering what medications I need to take.
responses: Based on your condition, you need to take Ofloxacin, Brompheniramine (E.N.T.), Simethicone (Degas), Pegaspargase, Lacosamide (Vimpat), Antihemophilic Factor (Obsolete), Thioridazine, Scopolamine, Emollients, Topical, and Barium Sulfate.

patterns: Hi, Doctor. I've been experiencing infrequent menstruation for a while now, and I'm not sure what's causing it.
responses: I see. Based on your symptoms, I recommend that you start taking Norethindrone (Loestrin Fe) to regulate your menstrual cycle.

patterns: I have been diagnosed with pneumothorax. What are the required medications?
responses: You will need morphine (Rms), fentanyl, midazolam (Versed), oxygen, zosyn, colistimethate, etomidate, ioversol, and pancrelipase (Pancrease).

patterns: Hi Doctor, I've been experiencing pain and swelling around my wrist and thumb for the past few days.
responses: It sounds like you may have De Quervain disease. We can prescribe you some medications to help with the pain and inflammation. You will need to take Meloxicam orally and apply Triamcinolone Topical Product and Diclofenac Topical Product at the affected area. You may also need Bupivacaine injection and Estropipate (Ogen) depending on the severity of your symptoms.

patterns: Doctor, I have a fracture in my vertebra. What medications should I take?
responses: You will need to take Teriparatide (Forteo) to improve bone density and also Iohexol (Omnipaque) or Iopamidol (Isovue) for diagnostic imaging.

patterns: Hi doctor, I recently found out that I have HIV. Can you prescribe any medications for me?
responses: Yes, for your HIV infection, you'll need to take a combination of antiretroviral medications. The specific medications I'll be prescribing for you are Emtricitabine-Tenofovir, Ritonavir (Norvir), Atazanavir (Reyataz), Kaletra, Efavirenz, Combivir, Lamivudine, Tenofovir, Fluconazole (Diflucan), and Zidovudine.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing pain and swelling in my salivary glands, and I also have a fever. I suspect I might have mumps.
responses: Yes, it is possible that you have mumps based on your symptoms. You will need to take a course of antibiotics to prevent any bacterial infections. I would recommend taking a combination of Augmentin and Clindamycin. Additionally, you should get plenty of rest and drink lots of fluids.

patterns: Hello Doctor, I have been diagnosed with subarachnoid hemorrhage. What medications do I need to take for it?
responses: For the treatment of subarachnoid hemorrhage, you need to take Phenytoin (Dilantin), Levetiracetam (Keppra), Celecoxib (Celebrex), Buspirone (Buspar), Labetalol, Ezetimibe (Zetia), Cefazolin, Fosphenytoin, Nimodipine, Naloxone (Suboxone), and Sennosides, Usp (Perdiem).

patterns: Doctor, I've been diagnosed with Acute fatty liver of pregnancy (AFLP). What medication should I take?
responses: You should take Ursodiol (Urso), Methadone, Glyburide, Famotidine, and Mecamylamine.

patterns: Doctor, I think I have ectropion. Can you please suggest me some medications for this?
responses: Sure, for ectropion you need to take Loteprednol Ophthalmic, Dexamethasone-Tobramycin Ophthalmic, Latanoprost, Azithromycin Ophthalmic, Fluorescein, Ginkgo Biloba Extract (Ginkgo), Pilocarpine Ophthalmic, Brimonidine-Timolol Ophthalmic, Cyclosporine Ophthalmic, Erythromycin Ophthalmic, Candesartan (Atacand), and Brimonidine Ophthalmic.

patterns: Hello doctor, I have a scar that's been bothering me for a while. I was wondering if there's any medication that could help?
responses: Yes, there are several medications we can try. I recommend using a combination of Triamcinolone Topical Product, Tretinoin Topical, and Desoximetasone Topical. Those should help with the scar's appearance and minimize any inflammation.

patterns: Doc, I recently found out that I have lactose intolerance. What medications can I take for this condition?
responses: The medications that can help with lactose intolerance are mainly enzyme supplements containing lactase, such as 'Lactase'. You can also try 'Polyethylene Glycol 3350 (Miralax)' to manage diarrhea or constipation that may occur due to lactose intolerance.

patterns: Doctor, I've been experiencing ear pain and muffled hearing lately. I went to the ENT specialist and they diagnosed me with Eustachian tube dysfunction. What medication do I need to take?
responses: You need to take a combination of medications for your Eustachian tube dysfunction. You should take Mometasone nasal spray, Pseudoephedrine (Pcm-La), and Ofloxacin for a start. If your condition still persists, other medications like Triamcinolone nasal spray, Cefuroxime, Oxymetazoline nasal, Robitussin Dm, Azelastine Nasal, Ciclesonide Nasal, and Levocetirizine (Xyzal) may be prescribed.

patterns: Doctor, my lower right abdomen is hurting really badly, and I have a fever. I suspect I may have appendicitis.
responses: Based on your symptoms, it does seem like you may have appendicitis. You will need a combination of medications to treat this. I am prescribing you Morphine for pain relief, Metronidazole and Zosyn to fight off any infection, Cefoxitin and Diatrizoate to reduce inflammation, Cefotetan to prevent infection, Iohexol for imaging, Ampicillin to treat any bacterial infections, Barium Sulfate to visualize your intestines, Meropenem to kill off any remaining bacteria, Lipase to help with digestion, and finally Rapacuronium to relax your muscles during surgery if required.

patterns: Hi Doctor, I think I have Graves disease. I have been experiencing excessive sweating, weight loss, and anxiety.
responses: Alright, we can start treatment for that. I am prescribing you the following medications: Thyroxine (Synthroid), Methimazole, Propylthiouracil, Propranolol, and Thyroid (Usp) (Armour Thyroid). Please take these medications as directed and come back for a follow-up appointment in three weeks.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing episodes of dissociation and it is affecting my daily life. What medication do I need?
responses: Based on your symptoms, I recommend a combination of medications. You will need to take Zolpidem (Ambien), Aripiprazole (Abilify), Duloxetine (Cymbalta), Ramelteon (Rozerem), Ropinirole, Mirtazapine, Fluoxetine (Prozac), Quetiapine (Seroquel), Trazodone, Clonazepam, Bupropion (Wellbutrin), and Venlafaxine (Effexor) to help manage your dissociative disorder.

patterns: My face has an open wound, and it is quite painful.
responses: You need to get a Tetanus Toxoid Vaccine (Adacel) to prevent any infection, and we also need to give you Bacitracin (Septa) to apply topically to the wound. Additionally, you can use Povidone Iodine Topical (Betadine) and Chlorhexidine Topical to clean the wound. We'll also use Ketamine to numb the area, Benzoin Topical to help the bandages stick better, and Lidocaine-Tetracaine Topical to keep you comfortable during the procedure. You should also take Clofibrate to reduce any swelling. Finally, we can use Fibrin Sealant Topical to seal the wound, but first, we'll clean it thoroughly with Sterile Water.

patterns: Doctor, I think I have dislocated my vertebra, I am feeling a lot of pain and discomfort.
responses: I understand. To treat dislocation of the vertebra, I would prescribe Hydrocodone for the pain, Dexamethasone Topical Product to reduce inflammation, Carisoprodol (Soma) to relax the muscles, and Fentanyl for severe pain. Additionally, Cefazolin would be given to prevent any possible infections, and Propofol would be used for anesthesia during any procedures. However, Erythromycin Ophthalmic, Mecamylamine, Grepafloxacin (Raxar), and Malathion Topical are not appropriate medications for dislocation of vertebra.

patterns: Doctor, I'm suffering from phimosis. What medication do you recommend for me to take?
responses: You will have to apply Betamethasone topical product on your penis twice a day for four to six weeks. This will help in reducing inflammation and facilitate stretching of the foreskin.

patterns: Doctor, I am experiencing severe nausea and vomiting during pregnancy. It's really affecting my quality of life.
responses: It sounds like you may be suffering from hyperemesis gravidarum. We can try a combination of medications to help alleviate your symptoms. I recommend starting with Zofran, Promethazine, Metoclopramide, and Pyridoxine. We can also use Trimethobenzamide if necessary and a topical product like Miconazole to help with any skin irritation. Additionally, we may need to consider Propylthiouracil or Methyldopa for controlling any underlying thyroid issues that could be contributing to your symptoms. Lastly, Nitrofurantoin may also be prescribed for treating any underlying infection that could be causing or worsening your symptoms.

patterns: Doctor, I have just found out that I am pregnant. Can you tell me what kind of medications I need to take?
responses: Congratulations on your pregnancy! You will need to take a few different medications throughout your pregnancy. First, you should take a multivitamin specifically designed for pregnant women, called Prenatal. This will ensure that you are getting all the necessary vitamins and minerals for both you and your baby. You will also need to receive the Rubella Virus Vaccine to prevent the virus from harming your baby. Additionally, you may need to have Rhogam, a medication containing Rho(D) Immune Globulin, to protect your baby from certain complications related to your blood type. You may also be prescribed Hydroxyprogesterone (Makena) to help prevent preterm labor. If you experience nausea, you can take Doxylamine (Unisom) to alleviate the symptoms. For yeast infections, you can use Butoconazole Topical. Finally, if necessary, you may be given Dinoprostone Topical to help induce labor or Oxytocin to help strengthen contractions during labor.

patterns: Doctor, I have been diagnosed with Thalassemia. What medications do I need to take?
responses: You need to take Folic Acid, Penicillin, Ergocalciferol, Imatinib (Gleevec), Oxytocin, Infliximab (Remicade), Fluocinonide Topical, Triamcinolone Nasal Product, and Terazosin. However, the Haemophilus B Conjugate Vaccine and Hepatitis A Vaccine are no longer required for Thalassemia treatment.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing severe bleeding during my pregnancy.
responses: It sounds like you may have placenta previa, a condition where the placenta covers the cervix. To help manage your symptoms, I recommend taking Thioridazine and Calcium Citrate as prescribed. These medications will help control the bleeding and ensure the proper development of your baby.

patterns: Doctor, I was diagnosed with epidural hemorrhage. What medication should I take?
responses: You will need to take a combination of medications to treat your condition. These include Cefazolin, Phenytoin (Dilantin), Factor Ix, Fosphenytoin, Eletriptan (Relpax), Atropine (Uaa), Tizanidine, Dexamethasone, Levetiracetam (Keppra), Aripiprazole (Abilify), Topiramate (Topamax), and Midazolam (Versed).

patterns: I have been diagnosed with septic arthritis. What are the medicines that I should take for it?
responses: The medications that are required for septic arthritis are Vancomycin, Linezolid (Zyvox), Cefazolin, Eszopiclone (Lunesta), Dicyclomine, Ampicillin, Propofol, Oxacillin, Nevirapine, and Chlorzoxazone.

patterns: Doctor, I think I have athlete's foot. It's itching and burning between my toes and on the bottom of my feet.
responses: I'm sorry to hear that. I'm going to prescribe you a topical medication to apply to the affected area. You can choose from a variety of options such as Clotrimazole, Terbinafine, Ketoconazole, Nystatin, Econazole, Fluconazole, Ciclopirox, Betamethasone-Clotrimazole, Clobetasol, Triamcinolone, Naftifine or Griseofulvin depending on the severity of the infection.

patterns: Hi doctor, I have been experiencing shortness of breath and chest pain. After some tests, I was diagnosed with pleural effusion. What medication do I need to take?
responses: The medications you need to take are Carboplatin, Cholecalciferol, Sodium Polystyrene Sulfonate (Kayexalate), Fondaparinux (Arixtra), Fludrocortisone, Lidocaine-Prilocaine Topical, Cefepime, Aprepitant (Emend), and Everolimus (Afinitor).

patterns: I have been diagnosed with Aphakia. What medications should I take?
responses: You will have to take Prednisolone Ophthalmic, Gatifloxacin (Zymar), Nepafenac Ophthalmic, Travoprost (Travatan), Moxifloxacin (Avelox), Pilocarpine Ophthalmic, Cyclopentolate Ophthalmic, Ampicillin, Bimatoprost Ophthalmic, Brimonidine Ophthalmic, Tropicamide Ophthalmic, and Colistin Sulfate Otic to treat your condition.

patterns: Hi doctor, I have been experiencing discomfort and pain in my vulvar area for quite some time now. Can you tell me what's wrong and what medications I need to take?
responses: Based on your symptoms, it seems like you have a vulvar disorder. The required medications are Estrogens, Conjugated (Usp) (Premarin), Estradiol, Fluconazole (Diflucan), Valacyclovir (Valtrex), Norethindrone (Loestrin Fe), Midrin, Metronidazole Topical Product, Dandelion Extract, Etonogestrel (Implanon), Sibutramine (Meridia), and Acetic Acid Topical.

patterns: Hi doctor, I have been having some health issues lately, and I think I might have a Vitamin B deficiency.
responses: Yes, it is quite possible. I would recommend starting on a course of Vitamin B12, Folic Acid, and Pyridoxine. These medications will help to restore the proper levels of Vitamin B in your body.

patterns: Doctor, I've been experiencing pain and swelling in my salivary gland. I suspect I may have sialoadenitis.
responses: Yes, that seems plausible. I recommend taking Clindamycin, Augmentin, or Zosyn to treat the bacterial infection causing your sialadenitis. You could also use Olopatadine Nasal or Ciclesonide Nasal to help with inflammation. If it is a fungal infection Terbinafine (Lamisil) is what you need. If you have iodine allergy or any kidney disease, then you should use Cefadroxil, and for diagnosis, we can use Iohexol (Omnipaque).

patterns: Hi doctor, I have noticed that my breast tissue has become enlarged and tender. I am worried it might be gynecomastia.
responses: Yes, it sounds like you have gynecomastia. The medication you will need to take depends on the underlying cause. For example, if it is caused by hormonal imbalances or medications, drugs like Tamoxifen or Exenatide can be effective. If due to a tumor, Pegvisomant will be required. Zileuton helps decrease inflammation if that is the cause. However, we would need to evaluate you further to determine the exact cause and prescribe the appropriate medication.

patterns: Hi doctor, I seem to have a painful and frequent urge to urinate, and sometimes there is blood in my urine. What's wrong with me?
responses: It sounds like you may have a urinary tract infection. I am going to prescribe you some antibiotics such as Ciprofloxacin, Bactrim, Nitrofurantoin, Levofloxacin, Trimethoprim, Cefixime or Cefpodoxime that can help kill the bacteria causing the infection. I will also prescribe you Phenazopyridine to help relieve the pain and discomfort that comes with it.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing fatigue, fever and chest pain for the past few weeks. I am feeling really weak.
responses: Based on your symptoms, it seems like you may have Histoplasmosis. I am going to prescribe you a medication called Itraconazole. You'll also need to take Metoprolol, Buspirone (Buspar), Kaletra, Cetirizine (Zyrtec), Esomeprazole (Nexium), Pyrimethamine, Lecithin, Ethambutol, Atovaquone and Leflunomide (Arava) to help with the disease.

patterns: Doctor, I have this itchy rash on my skin, and it's spreading rapidly. My lips and eyes are also starting to swell. What do you think it could be, and what medications do you recommend for it?
responses: It sounds like you might have erythema multiforme. I'll prescribe diphenhydramine, prednisolone, hydroxyzine, reserpine, mineral oil, selenium sulfide topical, hydralazine, clotrimazole topical, labetalol, erythromycin, and acyclovir for you to take to treat this condition.

patterns: Doctor, I have been diagnosed with scoliosis. What medication do I need to take?
responses: You need to take a few medications for your scoliosis. You require Glycopyrrolate, Levocarnitine, Acetylcysteine, Drospirenone, Penicillamine (Depen), Potassium Phosphate, and Bosentan (Tracleer).

patterns: Hey doctor, I have been experiencing pain and swelling in my right big toe joint. I was told by a friend that I might have bunions. What medications can help me with this?
responses: For your bunions, I would recommend you take Indomethacin, Trolamine Salicylate Topical, and Econazole Topical. They'll help with the pain and inflammation.

patterns: Doctor, I've been experiencing an irregular heartbeat and I'm really worried about it.
responses: Based on your symptoms, it sounds like you may be dealing with arrhythmia. The good news is that there are several medications that can help treat this condition. Some of the most effective options include Diltiazem, Amiodarone, Isosorbide, Flecainide, Adenosine, Sotalol, Propafenone, Mexiletine, Cilostazol, Metolazone, Ibutilide, and Dronedarone (Multaq). I'll review your medical history and determine which medication is the best fit for your situation.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing bone pain, headaches, and hearing loss. My X-rays also show an enlargement in some of my bones. What could be causing this and what medication would you recommend?
responses: Based on your symptoms and X-rays, it seems like you may have Paget disease. I would recommend a medication called alendronate to help prevent bone loss and reduce bone pain.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing sudden and severe facial pain for the past few weeks. It feels like an electric shock on one side of my face. What could be the reason for this?
responses: It sounds like you might have trigeminal neuralgia. The good news is that it can be treated with medication. I'm going to prescribe you one of the following medications: Carbamazepine, Gabapentin, Oxcarbazepine (Trileptal), Pregabalin (Lyrica), Baclofen, Lamotrigine (Lamictal), Eletriptan (Relpax), Desloratadine (Clarinex), Butalbital (G-1), Entacapone (Comtan), or Bromocriptine.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing severe stiffness and pain in my back and hips, and I find it difficult to bend or move around.
responses: Based on your symptoms, it is possible that you are suffering from Ankylosing spondylitis. I would recommend a combination of medications such as Infliximab (Remicade), Methotrexate, Etanercept (Enbrel) and Sulfasalazine to manage your pain and inflammation. Additionally, I would suggest topical products like Triamcinolone and Piroxicam gel for localized relief, and Tizanidine to help relax your muscles. In case you need any invasive procedures, we may use local anesthetics like Bupivacaine or Mepivacaine. However, Iohexol could be used if contrast injection is required. Lastly, please avoid alcohol and take Indomethacin as prescribed to alleviate your discomfort.

patterns: Hi doctor, I've been experiencing tingling and numbness in my hands and feet. I've also noticed some muscle weakness. Could this be a peripheral nerve disorder?
responses: Yes, it is possible. To treat your symptoms, I would recommend medications such as Gabapentin, Pregabalin (Lyrica), Duloxetine (Cymbalta), Amitriptyline, Nortriptyline, Ropinirole, Tenofovir, Lamivudine, Capsaicin Topical and Ubiquinone (Q10).

patterns: Doctor, I have a sebaceous cyst on my back. It's not painful, but it keeps getting bigger. What medications do I need to take?
responses: You need to use 'Tretinoin Topical' and 'Clindamycin Topical Product' for this condition.

patterns: Doctor, I am experiencing symptoms of poisoning caused by antipsychotics, what medication do you recommend?
responses: Based on your symptoms, we need to start with multiple medications to address your condition. You will need to take Charcoal to absorb the toxins, Benztropine to control the spasms, Divalproex Sodium (Depakote) to control your mood, Flumazenil to reverse the effects of the antipsychotics, Naloxone (Suboxone) to reverse any potential opioid overdose, Sorbitol to promote bowel movements, and Sodium Bicarbonate to correct the metabolic acidosis. In addition, we will administer Cefuroxime to prevent any possible infections, Thiamine to improve brain function, Propofol to induce anesthesia and Haloperidol to counteract potential psychotic symptoms caused by the poisoning.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing symptoms like oral and genital sores, skin rashes, and joint pain. I think it might be Behcet disease. What do you suggest I take?
responses: Based on your symptoms, you are correct that you have Behcet disease. To help manage your symptoms, I recommend a combination of medications. You will need to take alendronate to treat your bone thinning, lidocaine to help numb any painful areas, calcifediol to boost your vitamin D levels, ferric subsulfate topical to treat any skin sores, Iopamidol (Isovue) for any imaging tests, clorazepate to reduce anxiety, Infliximab (Remicade) to reduce inflammation, Tacrolimus (Prograf) to suppress your immune system, budesonide nasal product to reduce any nasal inflammation, and ropinirole to alleviate any restless leg syndrome symptoms.

patterns: Doctor, I have been feeling anxious and nervous all the time lately. Sometimes I can't sleep or concentrate on my work. I feel like I'm losing control.
responses: It sounds like you may be experiencing symptoms of neurosis. I would recommend medications such as Divalproex Sodium (Depakote), Risperidone, Haloperidol, and Olanzapine (Zyprexa) to help stabilize your mood and reduce anxiety. We may also need to consider Chlordiazepoxide for short term relief.

patterns: Hi doctor, I have been diagnosed with prostate cancer. What medications will I need to take?
responses: You will need to take a combination of medications, including Leuprolide (Lupron), Tamsulosin (Flomax), Bicalutamide (Casodex), Sildenafil (Viagra), Zoledronic Acid (Reclast), Tadalafil (Cialis), Finasteride (Propecia), Triptorelin, Paclitaxel (Taxol), Goserelin (Zoladex), Vardenafil (Levitra), and Dutasteride (Avodart).

patterns: Doctor, I am suffering from cerebral edema. What medication do I need to take for this?
responses: You will need to take a combination of medications for cerebral edema. This will include Ipratropium, Fluconazole (Diflucan), Topiramate (Topamax), Docusate (Colace), Lansoprazole (Prevacid), Labetalol, Lamotrigine (Lamictal), Amitriptyline, Mannitol, Somatropin, and Minoxidil (Rogaine).

patterns: I think I dislocated my finger and it's really painful. What medication do I need to take?
responses: You will need to take Cefazolin, Povidone Iodine Topical (Betadine), Pentazocine (Talwin), and Neomycin (Septa) to manage the pain and prevent infection.

patterns: Doctor, I have been diagnosed with birth trauma. What medications do I need to take?
responses: You will need to take Zidovudine, Phenobarbital, Carbamazepine, Nystatin Topical Product, and Devil's Claw Preparation.

patterns: Doctor, I have been diagnosed with chronic pancreatitis. What medications do I need to take?
responses: You need to take a combination of medications to manage your condition. These include Hydromorphone (Dilaudid), Oxycodone, Methadone and Bisacodyl (The Magic Bullet) for pain relief. You also need to take Pantoprazole, Sucralfate (Carafate), and Thiamine to heal the gastric ulcers that can develop in pancreatitis. In addition, you need to take pancrelipase (pancrease) or pancreatin to help your pancreas digest food, and megestrol (megace) to help you gain weight, and Sennosides, Usp (Perdiem) as a stool softener.

patterns: Hi doctor, I recently got hit on my arm and it has caused a hematoma. Is there any medication I can take to make it go away?
responses: Yes, for hematoma, I would recommend taking Benzonatate.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing flushing, diarrhea, and abdominal pain. I was diagnosed with carcinoid syndrome. What medication should I take?
responses: You will need to take Octreotide to control flushing and diarrhea, Esomeprazole (Nexium) to control stomach acid, and Oxycodone for pain relief. You may also need Atenolol to control heart rate, Furosemide to reduce fluid buildup, Sodium Chloride (Deep Sea) to increase blood pressure, Air to assist with breathing, Mecamylamine to treat nicotine dependence, Troleandomycin to treat bacterial infections, and Indium Oxyquinoline In-111 (Indium In-111 Oxyquinoline) for imaging and cancer treatment.

patterns: Doctor, I have a deep cut in my head. What should I do?
responses: You need to get a Tetanus Toxoid Vaccine (Adacel) first to ensure that you won't get tetanus. Then, apply Povidone Iodine Topical (Betadine) to clean the wound and Hydrogen Peroxide Topical as well. After that, use Bacitracin (Septa) and Tetracaine (One Touch) to prevent infection and pain respectively. Lastly, you might need a Lidocaine injection to numb the area around the wound.

patterns: Doctor, I have been noticing some growths on my skin that are brown, black or yellow in color. They are uneven and have a rough texture. What could this be, and what medication can I take for it?
responses: It sounds like you may have seborrheic keratosis. The medications that may help you with this condition are Tretinoin Topical, Clobetasol Topical, Fluorouracil, Fluocinonide Topical, Metronidazole Topical Product, Imiquimod Topical, Urea Topical, Ketoconazole Topical, Sodium Sulfacetamide-Sulfur Topical, Ciclopirox Topical, and Aluminum Chloride Hexahydrate Topical.

patterns: Hi doctor, I burned my hand while cooking. It hurts a lot and there are blisters on my skin. What can I do?
responses: You need to apply Silver Sulfadiazine Topical, Bacitracin (Septa), and Collagen on the affected area. You also need Tetanus Toxoid Vaccine (Adacel) to prevent infection. Use Emollients, Topical, Aloe Vera Topical, or Benzalkonium Chloride-Lidocaine Topical to soothe the pain. You can clean the wound with Iodine Topical and Silver Nitrate Topical Each. Sterile Water can also help.

patterns: Doctor, I recently had a spontaneous abortion, what medications do I need to take to recover?
responses: You need to take Methylergonovine (Methergine), Misoprostol, Oxytocin, Rho(D) immune globulin (Rhogam), Oxazepam, Cefoxitin, and Clomiphene (Clomid) to speed up your recovery.

patterns: Doctor, I've been experiencing painful sores on my genitals. I think I might have genital herpes.
responses: Your diagnosis is most likely correct. To treat genital herpes, I will prescribe you one of these medications: Acyclovir, Valacyclovir (Valtrex), or Famciclovir.

patterns: Doctor, I have been feeling very anxious and stressed lately and my emotions are all over the place. What do you think is wrong with me?
responses: It sounds like you may be experiencing an adjustment reaction. Patient: Oh, I see. What kind of medication should I take for this then?

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing severe pain in my upper right abdomen, and after several tests, I have been diagnosed with gallstones. What medications do I need to take to treat this condition?
responses: For your gallstones, you will need to take Dicyclomine and Glycopyrrolate to help manage your abdominal pain and cramping. During surgery to remove the gallstones, we will be using Rocuronium and Sevoflurane anesthesia. After the surgery, you will be given Neostigmine to reverse the effects of the anesthesia. In addition to these medications, we will also be providing Arnica Topical to relieve any post-operative pain and swelling. Finally, we will prescribe Cefotetan to prevent any post-operative infections, and Deferasirox (Exjade) to remove any excess iron from your body. Nitrous Oxide will also be used during surgery to help manage your pain.

patterns: I have been recently diagnosed with multiple sclerosis. What medication do I need to take?
responses: Interferon Beta-1A (Avonex), Glatiramer (Copaxone), Baclofen, Modafinil (Provigil), Oxybutynin, Tizanidine, Natalizumab (Tysabri), Tolterodine (Detrol), Amantadine, Solifenacin (Vesicare), Azathioprine, and Cyclophosphamide are commonly used to treat multiple sclerosis. We will need to discuss which medications are appropriate for your specific case.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing difficulty swallowing and a feeling of something stuck in my throat. I have also been experiencing bad breath and regurgitation of undigested food.
responses: It sounds like you might have a Zenker diverticulum. The medications required for your condition are midazolam (Versed) and meperidine (Demerol) for sedation during the procedure to treat your diverticulum. patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing some symptoms like diminished hearing, groin mass, and leg pain. What could be the reason behind all these?

This condition is associated with certain physical features and health issues such as hearing loss, swollen lymph nodes in the neck and groin area, and skeletal abnormalities that can lead to leg pain.

patterns: What is mental health?
Define Mental Health
responses: Mental health is a state of well-being in which the individual realizes his or her own abilities, can cope with the normal stresses of life, can work productively and fruitfully, and is able to make a contribution to his or her community
Mental health includes our emotional, psychological, and social well-being. It affects how we think, feel, and act. It also helps determine how we handle stress, relate to others, and make choices.

patterns: Why is mental health important?

patterns: What does it mean to have a mental illness?
responses: Mental illnesses are health conditions that disrupt a person's thoughts, emotions, relationships, and daily functioning. They are associated with distress and diminished capacity to engage in the ordinary activities of daily life. Mental illnesses fall along a continuum of severity: some are fairly mild and only interfere with some aspects of life, such as certain phobias. On the other end of the spectrum lie serious mental illnesses, which result in major functional impairment and interference with daily life. These include such disorders as major depression, schizophrenia, and bipolar disorder, and may require that the person receives care in a hospital. It is important to know that mental illnesses are medical conditions that have nothing to do with a person's character, intelligence, or willpower. Just as diabetes is a disorder of the pancreas, mental illness is a medical condition due to the brain's biology. Similarly to how one would treat diabetes with medication and insulin, mental illness is treatable with a combination of medication and social support. These treatments are highly effective, with 70-90 percent of individuals receiving treatment experiencing a reduction in symptoms and an improved quality of life. With the proper treatment, it is very possible for a person with mental illness to be independent and successful.

patterns: Who does mental illness affect?
responses: It is estimated that mental illness affects 1 in 5 adults in America, and that 1 in 24 adults have a serious mental illness. Mental illness does not discriminate; it can affect anyone, regardless of gender, age, income, social status, ethnicity, religion, sexual orientation, or background. Although mental illness can affect anyone, certain conditions may be more common in different populations. For instance, eating disorders tend to occur more often in females, while disorders such as attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder is more prevalent in children. Additionally, all ages are susceptible, but the young and the old are especially vulnerable. Mental illnesses usually strike individuals in the prime of their lives, with 75 percent of mental health conditions developing by the age of 24. This makes identification and treatment of mental disorders particularly difficult, because the normal personality and behavioral changes of adolescence may mask symptoms of a mental health condition. Parents and caretakers should be aware of this fact, and take notice of changes in their childs mood, personality, personal habits, and social withdrawal. When these occur in children under 18, they are referred to as serious emotional disturbances (SEDs).

patterns: What are some of the warning signs of mental illness?
responses:
Symptoms of mental health disorders vary depending on the type and severity of the condition. The following is a list of general symptoms that may suggest a mental health disorder, particularly when multiple symptoms are expressed at once. 
 In adults:
 Confused thinking
 Long-lasting sadness or irritability
 Extreme highs and lows in mood
 Excessive fear, worrying, or anxiety
 Social withdrawal
 Dramatic changes in eating or sleeping habits
 Strong feelings of anger
 Delusions or hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not really there)
 Increasing inability to cope with daily problems and activities
 Thoughts of suicide
 Denial of obvious problems
 Many unexplained physical problems
 Abuse of drugs and/or alcohol
 
In older children and pre-teens:
 Abuse of drugs and/or alcohol
 Inability to cope with daily problems and activities
 Changes in sleeping and/or eating habits
 Excessive complaints of physical problems
 Defying authority, skipping school, stealing, or damaging property
 Intense fear of gaining weight
 Long-lasting negative mood, often along with poor appetite and thoughts of death
 Frequent outbursts of anger
 
In younger children:
 Changes in school performance
 Poor grades despite strong efforts
 Excessive worrying or anxiety
 Hyperactivity
 Persistent nightmares
 Persistent disobedience and/or aggressive behavior
 Frequent temper tantrums

patterns: Can people with mental illness recover?
responses: When healing from mental illness, early identification and treatment are of vital importance. Based on the nature of the illness, there are a range of effective treatments available. For any type of treatment, it is essential that the person affected is proactive and fully engaged in their own recovery process. Many people with mental illnesses who are diagnosed and treated respond well, although some might experience a return of symptoms. Even in such cases, with careful monitoring and management of the disorder, it is still quite possible to live a fulfilled and productive life.

patterns: What should I do if I know someone who appears to have the symptoms of a mental disorder?
responses: Although Pandora cannot substitute for professional advice, we encourage those with symptoms to talk to their friends and family members and seek the counsel of a mental health professional. The sooner the mental health condition is identified and treated, the sooner they can get on the path to recovery. If you know someone who is having problems, don't assume that the issue will resolve itself. Let them know that you care about them, and that there are treatment options available that will help them heal. Speak with a mental health professional or counselor if you think your friend or family member is experiencing the symptoms of a mental health condition. If the affected loved one knows that you support them, they will be more likely to seek out help.

patterns: How can I find a mental health professional for myself or my child?
responses: Feeling comfortable with the professional you or your child is working with is critical to the success of the treatment. Finding the professional who best fits your needs may require research. Start by searching for providers in your area.

patterns: What treatment options are available?
responses: Just as there are different types of medications for physical illness, different treatment options are available for individuals with mental illness. Treatment works differently for different people. It is important to find what works best for you or your child.

patterns: If I become involved in treatment, what do I need to know?
responses:
Since beginning treatment is a big step for individuals and families, it can be very overwhelming. It is important to be as involved and engaged in the treatment process as possible. Some questions you will need to have answered include:
 What is known about the cause of this particular illness?
 Are there other diagnoses where these symptoms are common?
 Do you normally include a physical or neurological examination?
 Are there any additional tests or exams that you would recommend at this point?
 Would you advise an independent opinion from another psychiatrist at this point?
 What program of treatment is the most helpful with this diagnosis?
 Will this program involve services by other specialists? If so, who will be responsible for coordinating these services?
 What do you see as the family's role in this program of treatment?
 How much access will the family have to the individuals who are providing the treatment?
 What medications are generally used with this diagnosis?
 How much experience do you have in treating individuals with this illness?
 What can I do to help you in the treatment?

patterns: What is the difference between mental health professionals?
responses: There are many types of mental health professionals. The variety of providers and their services may be confusing. Each have various levels of education, training, and may have different areas of expertise. Finding the professional who best fits your needs may require some research.

patterns: How can I find a mental health professional right for my child or myself?
responses: Feeling comfortable with the professional you or your child is working with is critical to the success of your treatment. Finding the professional who best fits your needs may require some research.

patterns: Where else can I get help?
responses: Where you go for help will depend on the nature of the problem and/or symptoms and what best fits you. Often, the best place to start is by talking with someone you trust about your concerns, such as a family member, friend, clergy, healthcare provider, or other professionals. Having this social support is essential in healing from mental illness, and you will be able to ask them for referrals or recommendations for trusted mental health practitioners. Search for mental health resources in your area. Secondly, there are people and places throughout the country that provide services to talk, to listen, and to help you on your journey to recovery. Thirdly, many people find peer support a helpful tool that can aid in their recovery. There are a variety of organizations that offer support groups for consumers, their family members, and friends. Some support groups are peer led while others may be led by a mental health professional.

patterns: What should I know before starting a new medication?
responses:
The best source of information regarding medications is the physician prescribing them. He or she should be able to answer questions such as:    
1. What is the medication supposed to do? 
2. When should it begin to take effect, and how will I know when it is effective? 
3. How is the medication taken and for how long? What food, drinks, other medicines, and activities should be avoided while taking this medication? 
4. What are the side effects and what should be done if they occur? 
5. What do I do if a dose is missed? 
6. Is there any written information available about this medication? 
7. Are there other medications that might be appropriate? 
8. If so, why do you prefer the one you have chosen? 
9. How do you monitor medications and what symptoms indicate that they should be raised, lowered, or changed? 
10. All medications should be taken as directed. Most medications for mental illnesses do not work when taken irregularly, and extra doses can cause severe, sometimes dangerous side effects. Many psychiatric medications begin to have a beneficial effect only after they have been taken for several weeks.

patterns: Where can I go to find therapy?
responses: Different kinds of therapy are more effective based on the nature of the mental health condition and/or symptoms and the person who has them (for example, children will benefit from a therapist who specializes in childrens mental health). However, there are several different types of treatment and therapy that can help.

patterns: Where can I learn about types of mental health treatment?
responses: Mental health conditions are often treated with medication, therapy or a combination of the two. However, there are many different types of treatment available, including Complementary & Alternative Treatments, self-help plans, and peer support. Treatments are very personal and should be discussed by the person with the mental health conditions and his or her team.

patterns: What are the different types of mental health professionals?
responses: There are many types of mental health professionals. Finding the right one for you may require some research.

patterns: Where can I go to find a support group?
responses: Many people find peer support a helpful tool that can aid in their recovery. There are a variety of organizations that offer support groups for consumers, their family members and friends. Some support groups are peer-led, while others may be led by a mental health professional.

patterns: Can you prevent mental health problems?
responses: We can all suffer from mental health challenges, but developing our wellbeing, resilience, and seeking help early can help prevent challenges becoming serious.

patterns: Are there cures for mental health problems?
is there any cure for mental health problems?
responses: It is often more realistic and helpful to find out what helps with the issues you face. Talking, counselling, medication, friendships, exercise, good sleep and nutrition, and meaningful occupation can all help.

patterns: What causes mental health problems?
responses: Challenges or problems with your mental health can arise from psychological, biological, and social, issues, as well as life events.

patterns: What do I do if I'm worried about my mental health?
responses: The most important thing is to talk to someone you trust. This might be a friend, colleague, family member, or GP. In addition to talking to someone, it may be useful to find out more information about what you are experiencing. These things may help to get some perspective on what you are experiencing, and be the start of getting help.

patterns: How do I know if I'm unwell?
responses: If your beliefs , thoughts , feelings or behaviours have a significant impact on your ability to function in what might be considered a normal or ordinary way, it would be important to seek help.

patterns: How can I maintain social connections? What if I feel lonely?
responses: A lot of people are alone right now, but we don't have to be lonely. We're all in this together. Think about the different ways to connect that are most meaningful for you. For example, you might prefer a video chat over a phone call, or you might prefer to text throughout the day rather than one set time for a video call. Then, work with your social networks to make a plan. You might video chat with your close friends in the evening and phone a family member once a week. Remember to be mindful of people who may not be online. Check in by phone and ask how you can help. The quality of your social connections matter. Mindlessly scrolling through social media and liking a few posts usually doesn't build strong social connections. Make sure you focus on strategies that actually make you feel included and connected. If your current strategies don't help you feel connected, problem-solve to see if you can find a solution. Everyone feels lonely at times. Maybe you recently moved to a new city, are changing your circle of friends, lost someone important in your life, or lost your job and also lost important social connections with coworkers. Other people may have physical connections to others but may feel like their emotional or social needs aren't met. Measures like social distancing or self-isolation can make loneliness feel worse no matter why you feel lonely now. Reach out to the connections you do have. Suggest ways to keep in touch and see if you can set a regular time to connect. People may hesitate to reach out for a lot of different reasons, so don't be afraid to be the one who asks. Look for local community support groups and mutual aid groups on social media. This pandemic is bringing everyone together, so look for opportunities to make new connections. These groups are a great way to share your skills and abilities or seek help and support. Look for specialized support groups. Support groups are moving online, and there are a lot of different support lines to call if you need to talk to someone.

patterns: What's the difference between anxiety and stress?
responses: Stress and anxiety are often used interchangeably, and there is overlap between stress and anxiety. Stress is related to the same fight, flight, or freeze response as anxiety, and the physical sensations of anxiety and stress may be very similar. The cause of stress and anxiety are usually different, however. Stress focuses on mainly external pressures on us that we're finding hard to cope with. When we are stressed, we usually know what we're stressed about, and the symptoms of stress typically disappear after the stressful situation is over. Anxiety, on the other hand, isn't always as easy to figure out. Anxiety focuses on worries or fears about things that could threaten us, as well as anxiety about the anxiety itself. Stress and anxiety are both part of being human, but both can be problems if they last for a long time or have an impact on our well-being or daily life.

patterns: What's the difference between sadness and depression?
difference between sadness and depression
responses: Sadness is a normal reaction to a loss, disappointment, problems, or other difficult situations. Feeling sad from time to time is just another part of being human. In these cases, feelings of sadness go away quickly and you can go about your daily life. Other ways to talk about sadness might be feeling low, feeling down, or feeling blue.A person may say they are feeling depressed, but if it goes away on its own and doesn't impact life in a big way, it probably isn't the illness of depression. Depression is a mental illness that affects your mood, the way you understand yourself, and the way you understand and relate to things around you. It can also go by different names, such as clinical depression, major depressive disorder, or major depression. Depression can come up for no reason, and it lasts for a long time. It's much more than sadness or low mood. People who experience depression may feel worthless or hopeless. They may feel unreasonable guilty. Some people may experience depression as anger or irritability. It may be hard to concentrate or make decisions. Most people lose interest in things that they used to enjoy and may isolate themselves from others. There are also physical signs of depression, such as problems with sleep, appetite and energy and unexplainable aches or pains. Some may experience difficult thoughts about death or ending their life (suicide). Depression lasts longer than two weeks, doesn't usually go away on its own, and impacts your life. It's a real illness, and it is very treatable. It's important to seek help if you're concerned about depression.

patterns: Doctor, I have been experiencing sudden and frequent panic attacks. I don't know what to do.

responses: Well, based on what you're telling me, it sounds like you may be suffering from panic disorder. The best course of action is to start with psychotherapy and mental health counseling. Additionally, we should conduct an electrocardiogram to make sure that there are no physical issues causing your panic attacks. We will also need to perform a depression screen and a toxicology screen to rule out any other underlying causes. Finally, I would recommend a comprehensive psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy to help manage your symptoms.

patterns: How to give CPR??
what to do in a CPR?
What steps to take in a CPR??
How to help a drowning person in CPR?
responses: 1)For an adult or child, place the heel of one hand on the center of the chest at the nipple line. You can also push with one hand on top of the other. For an infant, place two fingers on the breastbone. 2)For an adult or child, press down at least 2 inches. Make sure not to press on ribs. For an infant, press down about 1 and 1/2 inches. Make sure not to press on the end of the breastbone. 3)Do chest compressions only, at the rate of 100-120 per minute or more. Let the chest rise completely between pushes. 4)Check to see if the person has started breathing.
